Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Bridging micro- and macroevolution in a top Neotropical predator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The large-scale, macroevolutionary patterns observed in the fossil record span millions of years, and the processes behind these patterns are responsible for generating the diversity in biological organisms that exist today. On the microevolutionary scale, examples of natural selection are common - both in nature and in laboratory experiments - and often can be observed over a few generations. A large advantage of working on the microevolutionary scale is the ability to manipulate organisms to understand the underlying mechanisms and processes behind observed patterns. However, extending the knowledge of microevolutionary processes to deeper time scales will be crucial to understanding the generation of biodiversity. Elucidating the contexts in which microevolutionary processes extend beyond short time scales aids both in advancing the clarity of evolutionary theory as well as strengthening application to broader non-scientific aims. Furthermore, understanding how complex traits are inherited across time scales and genetic diversity can have important impacts on biomedical and agricultural applications.

Neotropical army ants are keystone predators of leaf litter communities with broad geographic ranges and diverse physical forms shaped by dietary ecology. This project leverages existing genomic data demonstrating the macroevolutionary pattern for Neotropical army ants to determine whether changes in physical form at intermediate time scales occur due to heritable and non-heritable variation in existing lineages. The project explores whether change in physical form at the macroevolutionary scale can be reduced to one of the most basic Darwinian microevolutionary processes - natural selection by heritable variation. The data to address these questions will be generated by measuring variation in genetics and physical form, and using a range of quantitative genetic, genomic, and morphometric analytical methods. This work will take place at the Field Museum of Natural History, an ideal location for public science education, community outreach, and mentorship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes from the NSF-supported dissertation "Bridging micro- and macroevolution in a Neotropical predator" have been numerous in their intellectual merit, with two published manuscripts, three conference presentations, and two publications in the submission stage. Simultaneously, this funding has supported Dr. Max Winston, who has also engaged in a number of broader impact activities during the funding period. 

The first published chapter of the dissertation was featured in Molecular Ecology (DOI: 10.1111/mec.13846), titled "Early and dynamic colonization of Central America drives speciation in Neotropical army ants." In this high-impact work, we integrated phylogenomic, population genomic, and geographic evidence to show that early colonization of Central America across the emerging Isthmus of Panama drove parallel speciation in Neotropical army ants. The second published chapter of the dissertation is coming out in Ecology & Evolution (DOI: 10.1002/ece3.2932), titled "Novel approach to heritability detection suggests robustness to paternal genotype in a complex morphological trait." In this work, we pioneered and validated a new method to detect heritable morphological variation in non-model organisms, by synthesizing existing quantitative genetic and geometric morphometric tools. We then applied this to our own dataset to demonstrate that there was no heritable variation associated with paternal genotype of large effect in a complex morphological trait.

Our work has also been presented at a number of academic meetings. This includes the Entomological Society of America's 61st annual conference in Minneapolis, MN, where Dr. Winston won runner-up in 2015 in the President's Award for best student talk. This work was also presented at the 2016 Evolution meeting in Austin, TX in 2016, as well as at the GAANN retreat in Chicago, IL. Lastly, Dr. Winston presented a short presentation of his dissertation research to the Annual Board of Trustees Meeting at the Field Museum of Natural History in 2016, as an example of successful student research at the FMNH.

Lastly, the last two chapters of Dr. Winston's dissertation are in submission stage. The first, submitted to Scientific Reports, titled "Colony-specific caste allometry in a top Neotropical predator" uses high-resolution shape variation to quantitatively refine caste definitions, and demonstrates a significant pattern of colony-specific allometry. The second, almost to submission stage, is titled "Emergence from the subterranean environment shapes Neotropical army ant allometry", and treats the macroevolution of this complex morphological trait explored in the dissertation.
